item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: MDCM: A Framework or Model-Driven-Development of Cloud-integrated Mobile Applications
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Researches: Roberto Elero Junior and Ali Babar (roberto.elerojunior@student.adelaide.edu.au, This email address is being protected from spambots. You need JavaScript enabled to view it.)">ali.babar@adelaide.edu.au). Project Motivation
  • Mobile devices are limited when compared to other computing devices.
  • Cloud computing may overcome and reduce their limitations by extending their processing to the cloud platform.
  • However certain operations may be better performed rather on the mobile device.
  • We propose MDCM, a framework for building cloud-integrated mobile applications, which allows developers to determine how operations are performed (on-device, on-cloud).
Research Problem How can Model Driven Development and Cloud Computing Technologies be leveraged for enhancing processing on Mobile Devices? Technologies Leveraged   Project Context MDCM metamodel defines essential elements of the cloud-integrated mobile applications domain (see figure below). When a Control is modelled, the attribute type will determine if the operation is whether processed on-device or-cloud. Also, a code generator module is included in MDCM framework. MDCM (2) code generator is built upon Acceleo and requires a (1) MDCM model as input for generating (3) low-level source code as output, as described in the figure below.

item.title: Socio-Technical Structures For Shared Understanding Global Software Development
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Researchers: Mansooreh Zahedi and Ali Babar (mzah||maba@itu.dk). Project Description Given the evolution of worldwide communication in current century, collocated software development is not anymore a dominant practice. Growing demands for more complex and innovative applications and the competitiveness of IT world enforce making use of diverse expertise and pool of human resources from all around the globe. We witness software development teams are increasingly getting distributed across countries and even continents and become distant along different dimensions such as geography, time zone, culture and language. Changes in dynamics of software teams call up for renovations in software engineering practices to support knowledge sharing needs of distributed teams. Among which are strategies to effectively sharing requirements and associated knowledge between members. Despite numerous reports of challenges in literature, there is little empirically known about micro-level activities of GSD teams for sharing, clarifying and understanding requirements in early project lifecycle. This research project contributes to the body of knowledge on GSD by empirically exploring processes and practices of organizations in early project lifecycle. Looking through the lens of socio-technical structures, we recognize similarities and differences of sharing requirement knowledge in different contexts. We enumerate factors such as team structure, communication pattern, social relationships, maturity of organizational process and distribution of technical and domain knowledge could provision various approaches to deal with difficulties of knowledge sharing in distributed settings. Yet, each approach may vary in affordances for making shared understanding between the teams. Our empirical findings reveal emergence of a spectrum on which reliance on producing and maintaining comprehensive artifacts locate at one end. While making investments on developing and strengthening social ties for close collaboration, frequent communication and engagement locates at the other end. Therefore, we aim to understand interplay between different contextual factors and emergence of implemented knowledge sharing practices along the spectrum. Our ultimate objective is to assess shortcomings and strengths of adopted practices to propose suitable technological support based on contextual needs.

item.title: Cloud Platform to Facilitating Paramedics during Medical Emergencies
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Researchers: Aufeef Chauhan and Ali Babar (muac||maba@itu.dk). Project description: Health care experts, policy makers and organizations consider health information technologies, such as electronic health records a critical instrument to enhance efficiency of healthcare system. While health-related applications have matured in hospitals and other health institutes, most of them have administrative purposes rather than delivering actual clinical care, which is far more important, especially in cases of disasters and medical emergencies. To facilitate information availability to paramedics during emergency situations, we are working on a scalable service oriented architecture (SOA) framework that provides medical history information (such as patients health record and their medication status) to paramedics by displaying it on paramedicsâ mobile devices according to paramedicsâ privileges. We are working on a mobile application where medical personnel can use the patientâs CPR number as input to retrieve medical data from the SOA based cloud services integrated with existing healthcare data information system. In order to achieve the QoS (quality of service) requirements for minimal delay in information processing, we are taking advantage of elastic resource provisioning and scalability features of cloud computing. Through this project we are also accessing role of information technology for faster and reliable treatment of patients during medical emergencies.  

Figure 1: Mobile System for Paramedics

item.title: MobiFiRe: Mobility for First Responders
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Researchers: Aakash Ahmad, Ali Babar, Roberto Elero Jr. (aahm||maba@itu.dk||roberto.elerojunior@student.adelaide.edu.au) Project Context: Mobile Cloud Computing (MCC) can facilitate the computation and data intensive operations away from (resource-efficient) mobile systems to (resource-sufficient) cloud providers. We aim to exploit the elasticity and resource provisioning of cloud computing to offer computational, resource and energy efficiency of context-aware and portable (mobile) systems for emergency management. Project Focus: A high-level overview of the solution for a mobile cloud framework - supporting the collaborative activities of first responders - for emergency management is presented in Figure below. The solution comprises of a 3-layered architecture as follows.
  1. Context Aware Mobile System Layer â is the bottom layer of the solution architecture that supports the operations of the on-field activities by the first responders. The layers support the interaction and orchestration of the mobile devices (coordinator-peer setup) to communicate and share the context specific information in a given emergency management scenario.
  2. Off-Loading Cloudlet Layer â is the mediator layer as an intermediate between the mobility and the cloud layer. The cloudlets are particularly relevant to off-load the computations and data from first responderâs teams.
  3. Multi-tenant Cloud Layer â is the top-most layer that provides cloud-based resources (computation and data storage) to support the on-field emergency management activities. The information from the cloudlets is provided to the central cloud that ensures multi-tenant and virtualized resources for collaborative, on-field activities of the first responders.
Related Projects: S. Simanta, G. Lewis, E. Morris, K. Ha, and M. Satyanarayanan. A Reference Architecture for Mobile Code Offload in Hostile Environments. In Proceedings of MobiCase 2012: Fourth International Conference on Mobile Computing, Applications and Services, 2012

item.title: Portable Cloud Computing Deployment Framework
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Researchers: Christian Lyngbye clyn@itu.dk Project Context: Cloud computing often requires subscribing to public cloud vendors that have not yet adopted standards for their interfaces that control deployment and provisioning. There is often a difference in the interfaces between vendors that threatens their customers with vendor lock-in. Vendor lock-in occurs when a developer has designed their product for the interface of a specific vendor, then it might lock the product owner to that specific vendor. The developer cannot easily switch vendors without investing significant effort in redesigning the product which might be necessary if the vendor increases their prices or they fail to supply the service agreed upon in the Service Level Agreement. Different platforms and brokers have been designed to facilitate the deployment and provisioning across different vendor infrastructures. Project Objectives: We believe we can help application owners to deploy applications across existing cloud vendor infrastructures by providing portability for the application using mediation. First of all we wish to paint an overview of existing research and industry solutions. Based on our results we can extend or build our own solution to ideally provide portability for the current available vendors and also any future vendors. As shifts occur in the market place for cloud vendors our solution can allow customers to shift platforms without rewriting their application and the deployment and provisioning descriptors used.

item.title: TaaS - Platform To Provision Tools As A Service
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Researchers: Aufeef Chauhan and Ali Babar (muac||maba@itu.dk). Project Context: Cloud computing has proved its benefits to provide on demand resource provisioning as services. On demand resource provisioning and dynamic scalability are two primary characteristics of cloud-enabled applications that them from other applications. These two characteristics needs to be addressed within constrains of a particular domain. Project description: Aufeef Chauhanâs PhD work is focusing on providing a platform to provision tools as a service (TaaS) to facilitate global software development. TaaS are different from traditional SaaS applications from multiple dimensions. Location and security specific constraints are one of the important dimensions and are applied on not only the tools but also on the artifacts that are produced. TaaS also need to have dynamic scalability and resource provisioning according to the QoS requirements of the produced artifacts, which cannot be predetermined because the artifacts are generated by the tools at runtime, and their resource requirements can only be measured as artifacts are produced and evolved. Hence, the project is focusing on providing a reference architecture that is dynamically adaptable and evolvable to cater specific resource provisioning and scalability needs of TaaS. Project Objective: To provide metrics that can classify and rank tools according to their capability to satisfy specific static and runtime Quality of Service (QoS) characteristics, to provide runtime metrics that can measure resource provisioning and scalability requirements of the artifacts being generated by TaaS by the users of the tools at runtime and a dynamically evolvable reference architecture consisting of architecture styles that can facilitates to achieves QoS characteristics of the TaaS.

Figure 1: High-level view of Platform for TaaS

item.title: Architecture-Driven Process Support For Legacy Evolution To Cloudâ Computing
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Researchers: Aakash Ahmad and Ali Babar (aahm||maba@itu.dk). Project Context:Â With the widespread adoption of cloud computing, an increasing number of organizations view it as an important business strategy to evolve their legacy applications to cloud-enabled infrastructures. Hence, a large number of organizations intend to migrate their business-critical applications â so calledÂ legacy systemsÂ â to cloud enabled infrastructures. The migration to cloud computing is a knowledge intensive and tedious undertaking that need to be supported with appropriate processes, reusable patterns and tools. Project Objectives:Â To provide a framework as a set of migration processes and their underlying activities to support an incremental migration â exploiting architectural abstractions â of legacy systems to cloud-enabled infrastructure. Our planned tool support for migration shall provide customization and (semi-) automation of the migration processes as in Figure below.  

A Framework for Legacy System Migration to Cloud computing.

item.title: Software Systems & Services
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Our research in the area of software systems and services focuses on developing and/or rigorously evaluating methods, approaches, and tools for supporting the design, analysis, and evolution of complex and dependable software intensive system and services that meet both the functional and non-functional requirements. Our research in this areaÂ is stimulated by the need to improve the software systems engineering processes to produce high quality software intensive systems and services that can help organisations (i.e., private and public) to achieve their mission- and business-critical goals. Most of our research efforts have been focused on early lifecycle issues when designing and developing software intensive systems and services using different software development paradigms such as Global Software Engineering (GSE), Open Source Software (OSS), and Agile methods or leveraging emerging technologies such as cloud computing and mobile computing. Some of the areas of our competency are listed below. However, we carry out our research across topic areas; developing and systematically evaluating the most appropriate approaches to designing and evaluating software architectures for mobile cloud computing.   Software Architecture Cloud Computing Mobile Cloud Computing Global Software Engineering Evidence-Based Software Engineering

item.title: Social Computing
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Social Computing Leveraging social computing paradigm and technologies for innovation and productivity for sustainable societies.

item.title: Security & Privacy
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Security and PrivacyÂ research aims at building knowledge, processes, methods, and tools for engineering secure and privacy preserving software intensive systems and services. Our research take an interdisciplinary approach to understanding and addressing the challenges involved in devising sustainable and robust strategies and tools for designing, implementing, and deploying security and privacy preserving software intensive systems and services. Our research on secure software systems is focused on studying the causes, types, and mechanisms of security challenges to systems for cyber and cloud infrastructures.

item.title: Cloud Computing for Global Software Engineering: Designing Infrastructures and Supporting Migration
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Cloud Computing for Global Software Engineering: Designing Infrastructures and Supporting Migration

  Venue:Â International Summer School on Software Engineering Presenter: Ali Babar Affiliation: University of Lancaster Cloud Computing promises to enable organizations to have on demand scalable IT (i.e., computing, network, and storage) resources without making huge upfront investment. Like many other domains that stand to greatly benefit from cloud computing in several ways, it is increasingly becoming clear that cloud computing can also help organizations to address several challenges that characterize Global Software Engineering (GSE) paradigm, which has become an increasingly popular model of developing software with geographically distributed teams. This tutorial has been motivated by an important need of providing Software Engineering (SE) researchers and practitioners with knowledge and understanding about the potential opportunities, challenges, and solutions for leveraging cloud computing for supporting SE in general and GSE in particular. Hence, the goal of this tutorial is to introduce the key concepts of GSE and Cloud Computing, describe the challenges of GSE in general and providing tooling support in particular. It will discuss different opportunities, benefits, and challenges involved in leveraging cloud computing to address some of the key GSE challenges. Then this tutorial will focus on two important areas: Tools as a Service (TaaS) and supporting migration to Cloud Computing. This tutorial will highlight some of the promised benefits of providing TaaS to GSE teams . It will outline a set of architectural requirements for a cloud infrastructure for TaaS provision and a set of potential architectural solutions to achieve the key architectural requirements. This tutorial will also describe a detailed description of how to provide process and tooling support for systematically migrating applications and tools to Cloud Computing based infrastructures. The tutorial includes short lectures and interactive discussions, which are designed to help the attendees to better understand different concepts underpinning the methods and approaches for designing, evaluating, and refactoring architectures for cloud computing and identifying the potential areas of further research and development.

item.title: Tales of Empirically Understanding and Providing Process Support for Migrating to Clouds
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Tales of Empirically Understanding and Providing Process Support for Migrating to Clouds

  Venue: International Symposium on the Maintenance and Evolution of Service-Oriented and Cloud-Based Systems Presenter: Ali Babar Affiliation: University of Adelaide, Adelaide The title of his talk is "Tales of Empirically Understanding and Providing Process Support for Migrating to Clouds." Cloud computing has become an attractive option for acquiring and using IT infrastructure and services. In order to exploit the potential benefits of cloud computing, existing software and services need to be migrated to cloud-based infrastructures. A successful migration effort needs to be supported by a well-defined process and appropriate practices. However, there is a little evidence-based guidance for supporting cloud migration. One of our main goals is to experimentally understand the key technological, social, and organizational issues in evolving business critical software and services to cloud computing and devising and deploying appropriate solutions. To this end, they have been conducting and/or studying several case studies in industrial and academic environments. The lessons and evidence from these case studies have enabled them to pinpoint the areas of cloud migration that need immediate attention of practitioners and researchers, devise a process-centric support framework, and identify the educational and training needs for cloud migration.

item.title: Migrating Software Systems to Cloud Computing: Experiences and Lessons
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Migrating Software Systems to Cloud Computing: Experiences and Lessons

  Venue: International Conference on Software and System Process Presenter: Ali Babar Affiliance: University of Adelaide, Australia Cloud computing has become an attractive option for acquiring and using IT infrastructure and services. In order to exploit the potential benefits of cloud computing, existing software and services need to be migrated to cloud based infrastructures. A successful migration effort needs to be supported by a well-defined process and appropriate practices. However, there is a little evidence-based guidance for supporting cloud migration. One of our main goals is to experimentally understand the key technological, social, and organizational issues in evolving business critical software and services to cloud computing and devising and deploying appropriate solutions. To this end, we have been conducting and/or studying several case studies in industrial and academic environments. This tutorial is aimed at sharing the lessons and experiences from migrating enterprize and open source systems to cloud computing. The tutorial will discuss the technical and socio-technical issues to be considered and the process and tools support required for migrating to cloud computing. The talk will also highlight the the areas of cloud migration that need immediate attention of practitioners and researchers, devise a process-centric support framework, and identify the educational and training needs for cloud migration.

item.title: CREST Researcher Gets Funding For Security Research
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Congratulation to Thomas Hildebrandt for securing funding from The Royal Danish Defence College to carry out research on Cyber Security risks to ICT infrastructure of emergency management processes in the Danish Transportation and Energy sectors.

item.title: CREST will be hosting ASWEC 2015
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: CREST is proudÂ to host ASWEC (Australasian Software Engineering Conference) 2015. ASWEC is a leading forum for the software engineering profession in Australasia. The 24th ASWEC will be held in Adelaide, South Australia from September 28th to October 1st, 2015. The theme for the ASWEC 2015 is âEngineering Software for Innovation, Security, and Sustainabilityâ. More information can be found from the following link: http://aswec2015.org/

item.title: Talk on "Making Software and Software Engineering Visible"
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: CREST is delighted to announce that Prof. Ali Babar gives a talk at event hosted by Engineers Australia, IEEE, IET and TelSoc. Title: Making Software and Software Engineering Visible Abstract: Software is becoming increasingly pervasive in modern day living. We have been witnessing dramatic changes and improvements in our lives courtesy of software-based devices and systems. Whilst software has been enabling most of the social, economic, organisational, political, and technological innovation over many years, we hardly notice or think about software as one of the key drivers of innovation and productivity in this century. It is increasingly becoming clear that software and software engineering need to gain appropriate visibility for tangible and intangible societal benefits. This talk will highlight the role of software engineering for societal advantages in the developed, as well as developing, worlds. Professor M. Ali Babar will share some observations of and thoughts about why and how we can raise the visibility of software and software engineering for driving innovation and productivity. Date and Time: Tuesday 30th June 2015 5:30 pm for 6:00 pm start Venue Engineers Australia Level 11, 108 King William Street ADELAIDE SA 5000 For detailed information please visit: http://www.engineersaustralia.org.au/events/making-software-and-software-engineering-visible

item.title: Roberto Elero Junior has presented his project at Ingenuity 2014.
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Roberto Elero Junior, visitor undergraduate student at University of Adelaide and member of CREST, has presented his project titled "MDCM: A Framework Or Model-Driven-Development Of Cloud-Integrated Mobile Applications" at Ingenuity 2014. The event gathered more than 500 students across 250 teams, who were displaying their projects to thousands of high school students, industry reps and the general public.

item.title: Aakash Ahmad Presented His Research Titled âArchitecture-Driven Process Support For Legacy Evolution To Cloud Computingâ At University Of Adelaide
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: CREST researcher Aakash Ahmad presented his research titled âArchitecture-Driven Process Support for Legacy Evolution to Cloud Computingâ as an invited talk at the School of Computer Science, University of Adelaide on May 7, 2013. This research reflects the cloud computing theme at CREST. The presentation was focused on presenting some empirical observations, guidelines and lessons learnt from case studies of legacy system evolution to cloud computing.

item.title: Ali Babar Presented Mini Course On Systematic Literature Reviews
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Ali Babar delivered a mini course on systematic literature review during the XIII Brazilian Symposium on Quality of Software on August 5, 2014. The title of the mini course wasÂ Methods and Approaches for Conducting High Quality Reviews in Software Engineering. The key goal of the mini course was to teach the participant the process, methods, approaches of conducting high quality systematic literature reviews in software engineering.

item.title: Ali Babar Gave A Keynote Talk At The XIII Symposium On Brazilian Quality Of Software.
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: CREST research leader, Professor M. Ali Babar, gave a keynote speech at the XIII Brazilian Symposium on Quality of Software on August 5 2014, in Blumenau, Brazil. His keynote talk's title was "Knowledge Sharing Challenges and Strategies in Globally Distributed Software Development Teams." The talk was based on the ongoing empirical study of understanding the challenges involved in sharing knowledge within globally distributed software developers and appropriate strategies to address those challenges.

item.title: Ali Babar gave a talk on "Software Driven Innovation" talk to the..
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: In the last decade, we have witnessed dramatic changes in our daily life courtesy to software based devices and systems. Whilst software has been enabling most of the social, economic, organisational, political, and technological innovation, we hardly notice or think about the large impact software has in our lives. This talk will highlight the role of software in driving the innovation and productivity in both the developed and the developing Worlds, and provide key reasons why software engineering is (and will remain) one of the highly ranked professions across the globe.

item.title: Seminar Series - Software Driven Innovative Corporate Reputation Management In The Financial Services Sector
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: The concept of corporate reputation reflects the standing of a firm based on the public perception. Firms with high corporate reputation are better able to sustain superior performance. During the financial crisis, the corporate reputation of financial institutions has decreased resulting in a bad perception of the financial sector by the public. However, improving their corporate reputation is of major importance for financial institutions as they are heavily dependent on the trust of the market participants. In addition, tighter market regulation such as BASEL III as well as US laws require banks to monitor and manage their reputational risk. However, how can that be done? In this presentation, the use of innovative corporate reputation management software will be discussed as well as ways to deploy social media to monitor and potentially manage corporate reputation. This talk is based on an ongoing research and thus it may stimulate more questions and research opportunities then answers yet. 05:30 â Welcome 05:40 â 6:30 Talk (including Q&A) 06:30 â 07:00 â Networking (drinks and nibbles). Please share your intention to attend by sending an email to: ali.babar@adelaide.edu.au (for arrangements).   More information may be found on the file attached to this post.

The event has come to the attention of undergraduate and postgraduate students, professors, staff, and other interested people from the South Australian industry of software. This talk was part of the Software Driven Innovation Seminar Series of University of Adelaide.

item.title: Seminar Series - Developing And Validating A Practical Methodology For Cloud Services Evaluation
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Appropriately evaluating candidate Cloud services is crucial and beneficial for both service customers (e.g., cost-benefit analysis) and providers (e.g., direction for improvement). When it comes to performing any evaluation, a suitable methodology is enormously important to direct experimental implementations. Nevertheless, there is still a lack of a sound methodology to guide the evaluation of Cloud services. To address this significant industrial problem, we have systematically developed and empirically evaluated a generic Cloud Evaluation Experiment Methodology (CEEM) for Cloud services evaluation. In this talk, I'll talk about the common challenges in selecting and evaluating appropriate cloud services, development of CEEM using an evidence-based approach, and cases of using CEEM to address practical problems of evaluating cloud services. The talk will also cover the ways in which evaluators can perform systematic Cloud services evaluation to support critical decisions in selecting appropriate cloud services. Biography: Zheng (Eddie) Li is a PhD candidate at the School of Computer Science at the Australian National University (ANU), and a graduate researcher with the Software Systems Research Group at National ICT Australia (NICTA). Before starting his PhD, he received a Masters by Research degree from the University of New South Wales (UNSW). He worked for four years in industry as a software test engineer before coming back to university for his graduate degrees. He is the first author of 20+ journal and conference publications. His research interests include Cloud computing, Web Services, Software Cost/Effort Estimation, and Empirical Software Engineering. Date: 14th of November, 2014. 15:00 â 16:00 Talk 16:00 â 17:00Â Networking Please share your intention to attend by sending an email to: ali.babar@adelaide.edu.au (for arrangements). More information and presentation slides may be found on the file attached to this post.

The article was based on an interview with Professor Ali Babar on the vision and mission of setting up the centre to build capabilities and competencies in software engineering to support local industry. The full article can be found atÂ adelaidenow.com.

item.title: An Invited Talk On Privacy Invasion And Countermeasures
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Professor Ali Babar delivered a talk on privacy invasion and countermeasures at Open University, United Kingdom. Following is title and abstract of the talk. Title: Mobile Devices: Systemisation of Knowledge about Privacy Invasion Tactics and Countermeasures Abstract: Mobile devices have become pervasive computing and storage environments for work, leisure, and socialization. One of the key concerns is the cyber attacks targeting the privacy and data of mobile computing users. One of our main research goals is to systematically build a cohesive body of knowledge from the outcomes of the research efforts aimed at understanding the privacy invasion attack and data stealing tactics and devising appropriate countermeasures. To this end, we have been leveraging Systematic Literature Review method of Evidence-Based Software Engineering (EBSE). In this talk, Iâll present the findings from our effort to systemize the existing literature on the types of privacy invasion attacks and data stealing tactics and the reported countermeasures. The findings will be presented using the taxonomic frameworks built to help not only identify the areas where technological and organisational resources can be allocated but also provide knowledge-based guidance for the future efforts to devise and evaluate appropriate solutions.

item.title: Muhammad Ali Babar
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Dr. M. Ali Babar is a Professor of Software Engineering (Chair) at the School of Computer Science, the University of Adelaide, Australia. He also holds an Associate Professorship at IT University of Copenhagen, Denmark. Prior to this, he was a Reader in Software Engineering at Lancaster University UK. Previously, he worked as a researcher and project leaders in different research centres in Ireland and Australia. He has authored/co-authored more than 140 peer-reviewed research papers in journals, conferences, and workshops. He has co-edited a book, software architecture knowledge management: theory and practice. Prof. Ali Babar has been a guest editor of several special issues/sections of IEEE Software, JSS, ESEJ, SoSyM, IST, and REJ. Apart from being on the program committees of several international conferences such as WICSA/ECSA, ESEM, SPLC, ICGSE, and ICSSP for several years, Prof. Ali Babar was the founding general chair of Nordic-Baltic Symposium on Cloud Computing and Internet Technologies (NordiCloud) 2012.

item.title: Dr. Damith Ranasignhe
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Damith Ranasighe is lecturer in the school of computer science at the University of Adelaide. Since graduating from a Bachelor of Engineering, Damith has worked in Auto-ID Labs at MIT, the University of Cambridge and in The University of Adelaide, where he completed his PhD degree in Electrical and Electronic Engineering.
His current research interests are focused in the areas of Pervasive Computing, Lightweight Cryptography, Internet of Things, Human Activity Recognition, Wearable Sensors, Middleware for RFID and Sensor Data Management, Layered Information Architectures, and Data Fusion (RFID and sensor data).

item.title: Dr. Padraig O'Leary
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Dr. PÃ¡draig O'Leary is a Lecturer in Software Engineering at the University of Adelaide.Â Dr.Â O'Leary's main interests are Empirical Software Engineering and Health Informatics.Â Prior to this,Â Dr.Â O'LearyÂ was a Research Fellow, working for theÂ centre for Applied Research in Connected Health (ARCH) and the Irish Software Engineering Research Centre.
Dr.Â O'LearyÂ was a postdoctoral researcher with the Federal University of Bahia in Brazil. He also was aÂ lecturer in Dublin City University and Griffith College Limerick.Â Dr.Â OâLeary hasÂ worked as a software engineer within the financial sector with organisations such as Fineos and State Street Bank.
Dr.Â OâLearyÂ has experience with technology commercialisation,Â co-founding a software startup that secured funding from Enterprise Ireland and the National Digital Research Centre. He also has a Graduate Diploma in New Business Development with Dublin Institute of Technology.

item.title: Dr. Haifeng Shen
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Dr. Haifeng Shen is a senior lecturer in School of Computer Science, Engineering and Mathematics at Flinders University in Adelaide. Before joining Flinders University in 2009, Dr Shen had been an assistant professor in the school of computer engineering at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore since 2003. Dr Shen also has over six years working experience in industry as a software engineer, computer system administrator and programmer before becoming an academic.

item.title: Muhammad Aufeef Chauhan
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Research Interests: Aufeef is a PhD student at IT University of Copenhagen. Focus of his PhD thesis is to develop a reference architecture to provision of Global Software Development Tools as a Service (TaaS). He is also involved in research targeting at identifying reference architecture styles and patterns for cloud based systems, and migrating web-based applications to cloud.
Professional Experience: He holds a bachelor (BS) and master (MS) degrees in Computer Science. Before starting his PhD, he have been involved in software development activities in globally distributed environments. He have several years of industrial experience of working on financial applications; targeting solutions for prepaid debit cards and banking sector using JavaEE technologies in GSD settings.
Research/Teaching Activities: He has been a teaching assistant in Software Architecture and Cloud Computing courses at IT University of Copenhagen since 2011. Has also co-supervised few master students thesis/projects related with cloud computing and software architecture.
Keywords: Cloud Computing, Software Archtiecture, Global Software Development, Software Evolution.

item.title: Mansooreh Zahedi
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Mansooreh Zahedi is a PhD student atÂ IT University of Copenhagen. Her research interests include Global Software Development (GSD), qualitative research methods, empirical software engineering, knowledge management and human-centric factors in SE.
She holds bachelor(BS) and master (MS) degrees in Software Engineering. She has been working in industry before starting her PhD. Her research project is focused on software engineering processes and practices in GSD. She empirically studies cross-organizational collaboration of GSD team members during early project phases, knowledge sharing activities, associated challenges and potential solutions.Mansooreh has been involved in several research activities such as publicity chair for ICGSE'14, program committee member of short papers for EASE'15 and additional reviewer for ASWEC â13, ICSSP â13, EASE â14, ICSSP â14, APRESâ14.

item.title: Davoud Mougouei
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Davoud Mougouei received B.S. degree in Computer Engineering (Software Engineering) from University of Kashan in 2008. Then, he completed his M.S. degree in Computer Science (Software Engineering) at Universiti Putra Malaysia in 2013. He is currently a Ph.D. student of the School of Computer Science, Engineering & Mathematics, Flinders University. His research interests include software engineering, formal methods, and fuzzy logic.

item.title: Dr. Paolo Tell
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded: Position: post-doctoral researcher Bio: Paolo Tell is currently working as a post-doctoral researcher in the Pervasive Interaction Technology Lab (PIT Lab) at the IT University of Copenhagen (ITU). His research interests include software engineering and computer-supported cooperative work. Fascinated by activity theory, his focus during the PhD has been on leveraging activity-based computing for supporting cooperation in global software engineering (GSE) supervised by Prof. Ali Babar. More specifically, his PhD work revolved around understanding and experimenting with activity theory to build technological support for GSE teams. Currently involved in the NexGSD project, he sees this challenge as a stimulating opportunity to continue researching in both GSE and applications of activity theory by building on his previous research. â Prior to being involved in the NexGSD project, Paolo Tell received a MSc in Software Development and Technology from the ITU, a MSc in Information Technologies, and a BSc in Computer Science from the University of Udine. Before joining ITU, he has also worked for various companies in the area of Udine and Gorizia as a programmer. Among the projects followed, he participated in the Eurofighter Full Mission System simulator project: a cooperative endeavor involving Italy, Spain, Germany, and the United Kingdom.â Keywords: Global Software Development (GSD), Activity Based Computing, Software Architecture.

item.title: Zheng (Eddie) Li
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Research interests

Biography: Zheng (Eddie) Li is a PhD candidate at the School of Computer Science at the Australian National University (ANU), and a graduate researcher with the Software Systems Research Group at National ICT Australia (NICTA). Before starting his PhD, he received a Masters by Research degree from the University of New South Wales (UNSW). He worked for four years in industry as a software test engineer before coming back to university for his graduate degrees. He is the first author of 20+ journal and conference publications. His research interests include Cloud computing, Web Services, Software Cost/Effort Estimation, and Empirical Software Engineering. Eddie's research interests include Software Cost Estimation, Web Service Composition, and Evaluation for Commercial Cloud Services. I am also interested in Machine Learning (Data Mining), reinforcement learning and association rule mining in particular, although they are not in my current research focus.

item.title: Aakash Ahmad
item.dc:creator: crest
item.content:encoded:
Research Interests: Aakash Ahmad is a post-doctorate researcher in the Software Development Group (SDG) at the IT University of Copenhagen, Denmark. His research interests lie with architecture-centric evolution of software systems. He is currently working on the development of processes and patterns to develop and evolve cloud-based architectures.
Professional Experience: since 2008, Aakash has worked as a software engineer and technical consultant on various industrial projects. He has been involved in the development and delivery of software development courses both in the academia and industry.
Research Activities: Currently involved with the co-supervision of MSc. in Software Engineering thesis at ITU Copenhagen. I am also a reviewer for Journal of Systems and Software.
Keywords: Software Architecture, Software Evolution, Evolution Patterns, Cloud and Service-based Architectures
